sen.j: 玄関（げんかん）とは、建物の主要な出入り口のこと。
sen.e: Genkan is a main entrance of a building.
The word genkan refers to the main entrance of a building.
The word genkan refers to the main entrance of a building.

sen.j: 本来、中国の道教（錬丹術の内丹の法では体内にある気を巡らすための最初に気を通す場所のことである）、禅（達磨による禅の伝来の際、達磨の指示でディヤーナを玄（後に禪（禅）と訳す）と訳したともされる）などの用語で「玄関」とは「玄妙の道に入る關門」（「玄牝の関」）ことである。
sen.e: "Genkan" originally was a Chinese language term of Taoism (in the Neidan (spiritual alchemy) method of the Chinese alchemy, genkan is the first place where the ki (vital force that operates the body) is entered to circulate in the body) and a term of Zen Buddhism (it is thought that when Daruma (Bodhidharma) brought the Zen he directed to translate the word dhyana (meditation) into "gen" (later it became "zen")), meaning genpinnokan (gate leading to a road of genmyo (something black and not recognizable what it is but it may be spiritually deep).

Originally "genkan" was a Chinese term used in Taoism (in the Neidan, or spiritual alchemy method of Chinese alchemy, the genkan is the place where the ki (vital force that operates the body) first enters the body in order to circulate), and also a term used in Zen Buddhism (it is thought that when Daruma (Bodhidharma) brought Zen to Japan he directed that the word dhyana, meaning meditation, should be translated as "gen", which later became "zen"), and from these concepts genpinnokan (gate leading to the road of genmyo (something black and not recognizable as to what it is but potentially spiritually deep).
sen.cmt: Simplified. Punctuation, grammar, changed for clarity.
sen.e: Originally 'genkan' was a Chinese term used in Taoism (in the Neidan, or spiritual alchemy method of Chinese alchemy, the genkan is the place where the ki [vital force that operates the body] first enters the body in order to circulate), and also a term used in Zen Buddhism (it is thought that when Daruma [Bodhidharma] brought Zen to Japan he directed that the word dhyana, meaning meditation, should be translated as "gen", which later became "zen"), and from these concepts 'genpinnokan' (gate leading to the road of genmyo [something black and not recognizable as to what it is but potentially spiritually deep]).
sen.cmt: 括弧内の括弧を[]に変更" "→' 'genpinnokan→'genpinnokan'文の終わりの方の「and from these concepts」がどう繋がるのか不明です。

sen.j: 日本では書院造、禅寺の客殿や方丈などへの出入り口として造られたものである。
sen.e: In Japan, genkan was an construction built as an entrance of Shoin-zukuri style (traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma) or kyakuden (guest hall) and hojo (abbot's chamber) of Zen temple.

In Japan, a genkan was an entrance constructed in Shoin-zukuri style (a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma) for a kyakuden (guest hall) or hojo (abbot's chamber) at Zen temples.

In Japan, a genkan was an entrance constructed in Shoin-zukuri style (a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma), and in a kyakuden (guest hall) or hojo (abbot's chamber) at Zen temples.
sen.cmt: ＮＣの訳が原文と異なるので、「書院造」「客殿」「方丈」の出入り口となるよう訂正しました。

sen.j: 住居用に書院造の普及し始めた江戸時代以降に住宅に玄関が設けられたとされている。
sen.e: It is said that it was from the Edo period that residential houses began to have genkan when the Shoin-zukuri became popular for residential houses.
It was from the Edo Period that residential houses began to have genkan when shoin-zukuri became popular outside temples.
It was from the Edo Period that residential houses began to have genkan when shoin-zukuri became popular as a residential house.
sen.cmt: ＮＣの訳が原文と異なるので訂正しました。

sen.j: 日本ではほとんどの家屋において玄関で靴を脱ぎ、欧米では脱がないものと思われている。
sen.e: Many Japanese think that in Europe and the United States, they do not take off their shoes at home unlike the Japanese take off shoes at the genkan of most houses.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Many Japanese think that in Europe and the United States people do not take off their shoes at home, unlike the Japanese who take off their shoes in the genkan of most houses they enter.

sen.j: しかし、西洋でも地域やそれぞれの家庭によって脱ぐことがある。
sen.e: But, western people may take off shoes depending on the region and the individual home.

sen.j: また、東アジア、東南アジア、トルコなど広い地域で玄関で靴を脱ぐ習慣がある。
sen.e: In wide area such as East Asia, South-East Asia and Turk, there is a habit to take off shoes at the entrance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In a wide area, taking in East Asia, South-East Asia and Turkey, it is a custom to remove shoes before entering a building.

sen.e: So, the habit to take off shoes is not very special as Japanese think.
